{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2972353,"name":"Chris Lane","username":"CLane976","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/clane976/{size}/154670_2.png","created_at":"2021-10-18T16:13:55.492Z","cooked":"

I’m attempting to use an aftermarket brushless motor controller for a project of mine controlled by an old 4 slot FRC cRIO. A problem I ran into is that my motor controller requires an analog 0-5v throttle voltage to control it and the cRIO has no native analog output.
Does anybody have experience interfacing digital to analog converters with a cRIO or a RoboRIO? I’m just looking to generate 0-5v from a pwm port or a chip with I2C or SPI, I know RC converters exist but I worry about directly connecting the cRIO DI/O to the motor controller. I also worry about how much current the cRIO pwm ports would be able to supply after using a RC converter.

Any help or insight is greatly appreciated! Especially insight on the RC converters because I’m skeptical of them but I really have no experience with how well they work in place of a potentiometer.

Something like this should do the trick (for I2C).

sparkfun.com

SparkFun I2C DAC Breakout - MCP4725 - BOB-12918 - SparkFun Electronics

You've always wanted to output analog voltages from a microcontroller, the MCP4725 is the DAC that will let you do it! The MCP4725 is an I2C controlled Dig

FWIW, here’s adafruit’s example for communicating with it:

github.com

adafruit/Adafruit_MCP4725/blob/master/Adafruit_MCP4725.cpp

/**************************************************************************/
/*!
    @file     Adafruit_MCP4725.cpp
    @author   K.Townsend (Adafruit Industries)

        I2C Driver for Microchip's MCP4725 I2C DAC

        This is a library for the Adafruit MCP4725 breakout
        ----> http://www.adafruit.com/products/935

        Adafruit invests time and resources providing this open source code,
        please support Adafruit and open-source hardware by purchasing
        products from Adafruit!

        @section  HISTORY

*/
/**************************************************************************/

#include "Adafruit_MCP4725.h"
This file has been truncated. show original

By most device standards, this one is about as easy as they get.

Three major steps:

  1. set up and configure the I2C bus appropriately for the device
  2. Pack together the voltage you want at the output, and a flag indicating whether the setting should persist over power cycle or not, into a 2-byte message.
  3. Send the 2-bytes over the I2C bus to the device

And, verily, you become Bob’s nephew.

Thanks! That code example really helps. I’m using java so I’ll do some converting if I decide to use this chip, which I think I may. The code adaptation for an I2C device seemed daunting at first but this one seems simple enough.
